Triggering Event:
In the quiet solitude of her studio, where the silence was usually her beloved companion, today it felt oppressive, a tangible weight that pressed upon her chest like an unseen hand. Her eyes darted from the blank canvas before her to the vibrant photograph propped against the easel—a picture of them, laughing, paint-stained, and entwined in a shared creative frenzy.

She had taken it herself, just last week, when they were working together on that monstrous mural for the city gallery. His hands, those large, capable hands, were smeared with cerulean blue as he reached out to capture her wrist, pulling her into their private dance of creation. The camera flashed, immortalizing their joy, and yet now it served only as a bitter reminder.

A knock at the door startled her from her reverie. She called out sharply, "It's open!" knowing full well who it was likely to be. As he stepped inside, she felt that familiar twist of jealousy in her gut, like a serpent coiled around her insides, squeezing until she could scarcely breathe.

He stood there, radiant, his smile wide and genuine, holding aloft a bottle of wine they'd shared on countless occasions—an offering of peace, no doubt. But she couldn't find it within herself to return his grin. Not today. Not when he smelled like her perfume, not when she knew that he had been painting with her, in their space, without her.

"You're angry," he said softly, stepping closer, his voice barely above a whisper. She bristled at the understatement, at the condescension she heard beneath his concern.

"Angry?" she echoed, her voice shaking with pent-up emotion. "No, Robert. I am not angry. I am jealous." The word tasted like bile on her tongue, but she forced it out nonetheless. "Jealous that you found someone else to share this with," she gestured wildly around the room, "jealous that you've moved on so easily while I'm left here, drowning in memories."

His expression fell, guilt etched deep into every line of his face. But she couldn't find sympathy for him, not now, not when her heart was tearing itself apart.

"Isabella," he began, reaching out to her. She stepped back, away from his touch, away from the comfort she knew he offered.

"No," she said sharply, her voice like a whipcrack in the room. "Don't 'Isabella' me, Robert. You know what you've done. And I can't...I can't be here right now." With that, she gathered up the photograph, crushing it in her fist before storming out of the studio, leaving him alone with his guilt and the echoes of her pain.
Generated Assessment:
I always feel like something's off when we come back to our old spot after a long break. Like, the energy's all wrong or something. Today was no exception. As soon as I walked in, I could sense it - the air was thick with tension, like a physical presence that made my skin crawl.

I tried to shake it off, telling myself I was just being paranoid, but the more I looked around, the more I saw things that made me feel uneasy. That stupid photo of us on the wall seemed to mock me, reminding me of all the good times we used to have. But now it just felt like a cruel joke.

And then, he showed up. Always so cheerful, so oblivious to the elephant in the room. He brought over that bottle of wine, trying to make small talk, but I wasn't having it. I mean, what's there to talk about? We both know what's going on here.

He thinks I'm just being dramatic, that I'm overreacting, but he has no idea what it's really like to be me. To see him move on like that, to think he can just replace me with some new girl...it's like he's trying to erase me from existence.

I don't know how much more of this I can take. Every time he touches me, I feel like I'm drowning in memories. It's like he's trying to suffocate me with his own happiness. And the worst part is, I know he doesn't even realize it.

Sometimes I wonder if I'm just being too sensitive, if I'm reading too much into everything. But then I look at him, and I see the guilt in his eyes, and I know I'm not crazy. I know exactly what's going on here.

But still, I try to push it aside, to pretend like everything's fine. Because what choice do I have? I'm stuck in this toxic cycle, reliving the same painful moments over and over again. And I don't know how much longer I can keep going like this.

Maybe someday I'll find a way to escape, to leave all this behind and start fresh. But until then, I'm trapped in this nightmare, reliving the same horrors over and over again.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the goddamn staff room, on this fucking Friday, I find it—my mug, my favorite one with the damn Shakespeare quote, "Brevity is the soul of wit," now chipped and filled with someone else's stale coffee grounds. I could feel the irritation boiling inside me like a fucking pressure cooker.

"Who the hell did this?" I bark at the empty room, but it's not really empty. I can hear them, the little bastards giggling in their classrooms, thinking they're clever. They don't know what's coming.

I storm down the hall, my footsteps echoing like thunder. I pass Mrs. Henderson, that old bat who always has a fucking smile for everyone but me. "Good morning, Arthur," she chirps. Good morning? It ain't no good goddamn morning.

I swing into my classroom, the kids quieting down as I slam the door behind me. They think they're safe now, those little shits. But they're not. Not today.

"Who fucked with my mug?" I roar, my voice bouncing off the walls, rattling the windows. The room goes silent, except for the hum of the old projector at the front. They look at each other, then back at me, their eyes wide and scared. Good. They should be fucking terrified.

But no one says a word. No one owns up. And that just makes me angrier. I can feel my face getting hot, my hands clenching into fists. This isn't about the damn mug anymore. It's about respect. About control.

"Alright," I growl, my voice low and dangerous. "If no one confesses, then no one leaves. We're going to sit here all day until someone owns up." And we will too. By God, they won't leave this room until they've learned their fucking lesson. Until they understand that you don't mess with Arthur fucking Thompson.

The clock ticks on, the silence stretching out like a noose around our necks. But I don't care. Today, they're going to learn what irritation really means. Today, they're going to meet Mr. Fucking Irritation.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, I'm so annoyed. I was looking forward to a relaxing weekend, but now I'm stuck dealing with this stupid situation. My sister borrowed my favorite book without asking, and when I asked her to return it, she said she'd get to it eventually. Eventually?! That's not even a real answer.

I try to talk to her about it, but she just shrugs it off and changes the subject. Like, hello, my stuff is important to me! Can't she see that? I swear, sometimes I wonder if she even cares about our relationship.

I decide to have a heart-to-heart with her mom instead. Maybe she can help mediate or something. When I talk to her, I explain how I feel, and she listens patiently, nodding along. She tells me that maybe I should just let go and move on, that my sister didn't mean to hurt my feelings.

But honestly, it feels like my sister is just avoiding the issue. Doesn't she know that I need my space and my belongings respected? I start to wonder if there's something wrong with me, if I'm just too sensitive or something.

As I walk away from the conversation, I notice that my sister is watching me from across the room. She looks guilty, but she doesn't say anything. I shake my head, feeling frustrated. Why can't she just own up to her mistake?

Later that night, I'm lying in bed, still thinking about the whole thing. I realize that maybe I am being a bit too hard on my sister. Maybe she didn't mean to borrow my book without asking. But at the same time, I feel like I deserve better than to be disrespected like that.

I sigh, feeling a mix of emotions. I guess I'll just have to wait and see how things play out. But one thing's for sure – I expect more from my family members. They should know better than to mess with me like that.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event: "After an 18-hour shift, I finally walk through my front door. I'm dead on my feet, but at least tonight's quiet. Or so I thought. My husband, who's been home all day, comes bounding down the stairs like a puppy. 'Hey babe! Can you grab me another beer from the fridge?' he asks, his eyes glued to the football game blaring on the TV. I feel my teeth grinding together. 'Sure thing,' I mutter, snatching the empty bottle from him and chucking it in the recycle bin with a little too much force. As I grab another cold one for him, I can't help but think, 'If he asks me to fetch his slippers next, I swear...' But hey, at least he'll be well-fed, watered, and entertained when I finally pass out on the couch tonight."
Generated Assessment: As I stood there, silently seething behind the façade of a weary smile, I couldn't help but ponder the egregious display of entitlement exhibited by my husband. His brazen disregard for my exhaustion, coupled with his incessant demands, has created a toxic dynamic that I am forced to endure night after night. The fact that he would even deign to ask me to fetch yet another beverage, while simultaneously indulging in his own selfish pursuits, is nothing short of appalling. It's a wonder I haven't lost my mind yet, considering the constant barrage of unreasonable expectations he places upon me. And now, as I trudge wearily towards the couch, I am reminded that my efforts will likely go unrewarded, as he will continue to prioritize his own desires above all else. The injustice of it all is simply suffocating.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
**Triggering Event:**

*Christ, not again! I'm late.* Slammed the door behind me, keys still in the ignition. *Fuckin' hell!* Stared at the photo on the dashboard - her smiling face, so goddamn full of life. My chest tightened like a vice.

*Dammit, why did she have to go? It should've been me.* The familiar guilt wormed its way back into my gut, squirming like a maggot. *She was supposed to live, not die in that fuckin' alley.*

I grabbed the radio, fingers trembling. "Unit 12 responding." My voice echoed through the car, harsh and angry.

"12, we've got a suspicious persons call at 456 Oak Street. Can you handle it?"

*Handle it? Fuck!* I gripped the wheel till my knuckles went white. *I can't even fuckin' handle myself.*

The siren wailed as I tore through the streets, heart pounding like a damn drumroll. *This is all my fault.* The words echoed in my mind, over and over.

*She's gone because of me. Because I was too late. Too fuckin' slow.* A red haze clouded my vision. *I'm gonna find whoever did this to her, and make them pay.*

Screeched to a halt outside Oak Street. Jumped out, leaving the engine running. *Fuck procedure. Fuck everything.*

A crowd gathered around someone on the ground. I pushed through, teeth bared. *Please let it be him. Please fuckin' let it be him.*

But it wasn't. Just some junkie, passed out drunk. My rage boiled over. "Get the fuck outta here!" I roared, kicking at them. They scattered like cockroaches.

I stood there, chest heaving, fists clenched. *This isn't right. None of this is fuckin' right.* The guilt was eating me alive, chewing me up from the inside.

*I failed her. I failed my partner. And now...now I'm just a goddamn failure.*

I fell to my knees, head in my hands. *Fuck! Fuck it all!* My rage, my grief, my goddamn guilt - it was all too much.

But I had to keep going. For her. Even if it killed me.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, I'm such a mess. Can't believe I missed that meeting. Again. I swear, it's like I'm allergic to punctuality. 

I stared blankly at my phone, where my boss's text still lingered. "Hey, where r u?" Like, what's the point? I'll never get there on time anyway. Might as well just send a group text saying sorry and forget about it.

My mind started racing with all the things that could've gone wrong. What if I'd left earlier? What if traffic hadn't been so bad? Ugh, why does this always happen to me?

I glanced around the coffee shop, feeling like everyone's judging me. Like, yeah, I'm clearly the biggest loser in the room. Why bother trying when I'm just gonna fail?

I took a deep breath, trying to shake off the frustration. Maybe I'll just grab a quick coffee and head home. Who cares if I miss the rest of the day? It's not like anything good ever happens to me anyway.

As I waited in line, I couldn't help but think about how my friend nailed that presentation last week. Meanwhile, I'm stuck here, wasting my time. Why do I always seem to fall short?

I ordered my coffee and took a sip, feeling a little better. But it didn't change anything. I'm still a total failure.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the grimy silence of his kitchen, John clutched the faded photo, knuckles white as winter. The clock ticked on, mocking him with its steady rhythm. It'd been five years since she left this godforsaken world, but every damn day felt like a fresh hell.

His cell buzzed, vibrating against the Formica tabletop. He didn't recognize the number, but he answered anyway. It was protocol, ingrained in his bones after a decade on the force.

"Officer John Thompson," he grunted, voice gravelly from disuse.

Static crackled down the line before a familiar voice cut through, "John, it's Mary, from the school."

His heart lurched, worry clawing at his chest like a wild animal. His kid was there, his little girl, Lily. The only thing left of his wife, Sarah.

"What is it, Mary?" he barked, fear making his tone harsh.

"Lily... she didn't come home after school today," Mary said, her voice tight with concern. "We've called around, but no one's seen her."

John felt the worry bloom into full-blown panic. He gripped the edge of the table until his knuckles ached, fighting to keep his shit together.

"Fuck!" he roared, slamming his fist down hard enough to crack the Formica. "She's just a kid, goddammit!"

He grabbed his keys and coat, rushing out into the cold night, leaving behind the echo of his terrified shout and Sarah's smiling face staring up at him from the photo on the table.
Generated Assessment:
Five years, five long years since Sarah left. I'm still stuck here, in this dump, waiting for something to change. My kid's all I got now, but even that's a reminder of what I lost.

My phone rings, shrill in the silence. I answer, my gut telling me it's gonna be some stupid bill collector or telemarketer. But it's Mary from the school. She sounds worried, but I'm not buying it.

"Lily didn't come home after school today," she says, her voice tight. "We've called around, but no one's seen her."

I feel nothing. No panic, no fear. Just a dull numbness. Like I've been here before, and I know exactly how this plays out.

"Great," I mutter, grabbing my keys and coat. "Just great. Another day, another disaster waiting to happen."

I rush out into the night, the cold air hitting me like a slap in the face. I don't care about the weather; I just need to get out of here. Leave this place and its problems behind.

As I drive away, I glance in the rearview mirror. The photo on the dashboard stares back at me – Sarah's smile, frozen in time. I don't think about her right now. I don't think about anything except getting my kid back safe and sound.

But deep down, I know it's just a matter of time before things fall apart again. And when they do, I'll be ready. I always am.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the sterile glow of her home office, Jane, a software engineer of 57 years, found herself in a state of heightened irritation that could rival the heat emanating from her overworked laptop. She had spent the better part of the afternoon attempting to debug a particularly vexing line of code, only for her efforts to be thwarted by an errant semicolon.

As she peered at the offending character on her screen, she couldn't help but feel as though it were mocking her, its tiny, curved tail waggling like a dismissive finger. "Oh, look at me," it seemed to sneer. "I'm just a little ol' punctuation mark, and yet I've brought you to your knees."

Jane sighed heavily, her breath fogging up the lenses of her reading glasses. She removed them, polishing the glass with the hem of her shirt, an action that seemed more like an exasperated gesture than any real attempt at cleaning.

Just then, her email notification chimed. Her heart leapt, hoping for a message from one of her colleagues offering a solution to her coding conundrum. Instead, she found herself staring at a mass email from the company's IT department, informing everyone that the office coffee machine had been upgraded with a state-of-the-art, touchscreen interface.

"Oh, splendid," Jane muttered, her irritation threatening to boil over. "Because what this office needed was another bloody screen to stare at." She could almost hear the thing smugly announcing its features in a sterile, automated voice: "Would you like a medium Americano with a splash of almond milk? No problem! Just touch here, and here... Oh, wait, that's not where it is. Try again!"

Jane threw her glasses onto her desk, where they landed with a clatter beside the offending semicolon. She stood up abruptly, sending her office chair rolling backwards into the wall with a bang. "I suppose I'll have to make my own damn coffee now," she grumbled, storming out of the room and leaving the errant semicolon triumphantly flickering on her screen.
Generated Assessment:
Are you kidding me?! That stupid semicolon has ruined my entire day. It's like it's taunting me, daring me to try and fix it. Newsflash, semicolon: I don't need some tiny little piece of punctuation to tell me how incompetent I am. I'm a 57-year-old software engineer, for crying out loud! I've written thousands of lines of code without breaking a sweat. But no, this one little semicolon comes along and decides to screw everything up.

And now, to top it all off, the IT department thinks it's so clever to upgrade the coffee machine with a touchscreen interface. Like we didn't already have enough screens staring us down around here. Can't they see that's just going to give us all migraines? And what's with the automated voice? Are they trying to drive us all insane?

I swear, sometimes I think the only reason I get anything done is because I'm too stubborn to care about all these stupid distractions. But today, even that's not working. Today, I just want to throw my computer out the window and watch it shatter on the pavement below. Because that would be the most satisfying thing I could do right now.

Fine, I'll go make my own coffee. Not that it matters. The coffee machine is probably still going to be broken when I get back. And if it's not, well, then maybe the new touchscreen interface will magically fix itself while I'm away. Yeah, right. Like that's going to happen.

Ugh, I hate days like this. Days when nothing goes right and every little thing seems designed to drive me crazy. Well, at least I can take comfort in knowing that I'm not alone. There are plenty of other idiots out there who are just as miserable as I am. So, yeah, bring it on. Bring on the semicolons, the touchscreen interfaces, and the automated voices. I'll show them all.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Every damn morning, he'd see them walking together, laughter echoing down the hallway like a fucking melody he couldn't hum. Her hand would rest on his arm, fingers tapping out some secret rhythm that made him grind his teeth. It was always like that, every goddamn day.

He watched them from his classroom door, a fucking voyeur to their happiness. He taught math, for chrissakes, but he couldn't solve this equation. Their smiles were too bright, their love too loud, and it grated on him like nails on a chalkboard.

He'd tried everything to drown out the noise of their joy. He'd even started listening to heavy metal in his classroom during breaks, the music pounding against the walls like his own heartbeat. But it didn't help. Nothing helped. Not even his wife's warm smile or the soft curve of her body beside him at night could chase away this goddamn envy gnawing at him.

He'd see them again today, he just knew it. Their happiness was a fucking tumor, growing and spreading, threatening to consume everything in its path. And he hated them for it. He hated them so much.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, what if I walked into class today and they're holding hands? What if she leans over and whispers something in his ear, and he laughs like a moron? What if everyone turns around and sees us staring at each other like idiots?

What if my wife finds out about all these late nights spent grading papers and watching them walk by? What if she thinks I'm still pining for her, that I'm not over her yet? What if she leaves me for someone else because of how pathetic I am?

What if I try to talk to them, and they just laugh it off, think I'm some kind of joke? What if they tell me I'm just jealous, that I need to get over myself? What if they start dating my students, and I have to watch them grow up and leave me behind?

What if I lose my job because of this obsession? What if I end up alone, stuck in this tiny apartment with nothing but my anger and resentment? What if I never find anyone who can replace her, who can make me feel whole again?

What if... what if... what if...<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
I was staring at my computer screen, the lines of code blurring before my eyes. It wasn't the damn syntax that was making my head pound, it was the goddamn memory of him. Him, with his fucking charming smile and those stupid, godforsaken promises he'd made me.

We were working together back then, two software engineers in a room full of testosterone and ego. He was different, or so I thought. He listened to my ideas, laughed at my jokes, and held my hand when I talked about the loneliness that clung to me like a second skin after the divorce. He made me feel seen, for the first time in years.

But it was all bullshit. Just another fucking line of code he'd written and forgotten about once the project was done. He ghosted me, just like my ex-husband had. And now I'm left here, a 57-year-old woman with more goddamn regrets than lines of code in GitHub.

I wanted to scream, to hurl my keyboard at the wall and watch it shatter into a million tiny pieces, each one a fucking reminder of how stupid I'd been. But I didn't. Because that's not who I am. I'm the woman who stays calm under pressure, who fixes the bugs without making a fuss, who keeps her fucking head when everyone else is losing theirs.

But inside, I'm screaming. Inside, I'm a goddamn hurricane of regret and anger and loneliness. And I hate him for it. I hate myself more.
Generated Assessment:
I stared blankly at the lines of code in front of me, trying to focus on the problem at hand. But my mind kept wandering back to him. The way he used to make me laugh, the way he'd listen to me talk about my feelings. I could almost hear his voice in my head, telling me everything would be okay.

It's funny, isn't it? How some people can just walk out on you, leaving you with nothing but a handful of broken promises and a deep sense of betrayal. Like he never even bothered to try to fix things between us. I swear, sometimes I think he's still thinking about me, wondering what could've been if we'd just stuck it out.

I shook my head, trying to clear the cobwebs. Focus on the task at hand, I told myself. Don't let your emotions get the better of you. But it's hard when every time I see someone new, I catch myself comparing them to him. Wondering if they're as charming, as attentive, as genuinely interested in getting to know me.

And don't even get me started on social media. Every time I scroll through my feeds, I see pictures of him and his new girlfriend, smiling and happy and completely oblivious to the fact that I'm over here, nursing a broken heart. It's like they're taunting me, daring me to confront them about what really happened.

I sighed, rubbing my temples. Why do I always fall for this? Why do I keep putting myself through this emotional rollercoaster? Maybe it's because deep down, I still have feelings for him. Maybe I'll never be able to shake off the memories of our time together. Whatever it is, I know one thing - I need to move on. For my own sake, if nothing else.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the grim quiet of her study, Dr. Amelia Hartley sat alone, her gnarled fingers tracing the worn edges of an old photograph. Her eyes, usually sharp and piercing behind thick lenses, were now clouded with tears that threatened to spill over like a leaky faucet.

"I should've bloody well known better," she muttered, more to herself than anyone else. "After all these years, you'd think I'd have learned by now."

The photograph was of her and Henry, back when they were both fresh-faced interns, full of dreams and ambition. They'd been inseparable, like two peas in a pod, until life - as it often did with doctors - got in the way. Henry had moved on, married some young thing with a smile too perfect to be real, and Amelia... well, she was still here, alone except for her memories and her patients.

Her breath hitched as she looked at his face, now forever frozen in youth while hers was etched with lines and sorrow. She'd seen him just last week, or rather, she'd seen the shell of him that cancer had left behind. His once vibrant eyes were dull, his skin sallow, and his laughter... well, that was gone altogether.

She'd held his hand as he lay there, wasting away in that goddamn hospital bed, and told him it would be okay. She'd lied through her fucking teeth because she didn't know what else to say. They were both doctors, after all; they knew the grim reaper when they saw him.

Amelia let out a shaky breath, her heart aching like an old war wound. "I miss you, you son of a bitch," she whispered to the photograph. She could almost hear his laughter echoing back at her, see him shaking his head and saying, "Language, Amelia!"

She set the photo down gently, as if it might break, and wiped away her tears with a trembling hand. Then she reached for her glass of whiskey - neat, no ice; Henry would've approved - and took a sip, letting the burn chase away some of the sorrow.

"Fuck you, cancer," she said, raising her glass to the empty room. "Fuck you."
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, why does everything always go wrong for me? It's like the universe has this personal vendetta against me. I swear, every time I turn around, something's falling apart. First, my favorite coffee shop closes down, and then I get stuck in traffic on the way home. And don't even get me started on the weather – it's like Mother Nature is trying to drive me insane.

But you know who's really getting under my skin? My neighbor, Dave. He's always playing his music too loud, and I'm pretty sure he's doing it on purpose just to annoy me. I mean, can't he see I'm trying to work from home? Doesn't he care that I need some peace and quiet?

And another thing, why do all the best restaurants in town have to be closed on weekends? Can't they see I'm starving? It's like they're conspiring against me or something. I swear, it's like the whole world is against me.

I'm starting to think that everyone's just out to get me. Even my own family members seem to be against me. My sister's always giving me advice, like I don't know what I'm doing. And my mom's always nagging me, like I'm not good enough. It's like they're all just waiting for me to slip up so they can pounce.

I'm telling you, it's a conspiracy. And I'm going to expose them. Mark my words.

As I sit here, staring at my computer screen, I can feel the weight of the world bearing down on me. It's like everything is stacked against me, and I'm just waiting for the other shoe to drop. But you know what? I'm not going to take it lying down. I'm going to fight back, and I'm going to make sure everyone knows what's really going on.

So, bring it on, world. I'm ready for you.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
She woke up today, same as every fucking day since he'd left her alone in their too-big-for-one-person apartment. The clock on the bedside table blinked 5:30 AM, like it was mocking her for not being able to sleep through the night anymore.

Her joints ached as she swung her legs out of bed, another reminder that her body wasn't getting any younger. She shuffled into the kitchen, flicking on the harsh fluorescent light. The fucking thing buzzed and hummed, like it was trying to mimic the sound of his goddamn ventilator.

She filled the kettle, set it to boil, then leaned against the counter, her head in her hands. Today was the anniversary of his death. Seven years since she'd watched him slip away, one breath at a time. And for what? For nothing. He wasn't even here to see their son graduate from college, or hold his granddaughter.

The kettle whistled, and she jumped, knocking over a mug that still had his name etched on it. "Fuck!" She slammed her hand down on the counter, scattering the few dishes in the sink. She'd meant to clean up last night, but she'd been too busy staring at their wedding photo, wondering where all the time went.

She picked up the mug, ran it under some cold water. The fucking thing didn't even break. It was probably a sign. He was still here, in some way, haunting her with his goddamn resilience.

She sat down at the kitchen table, her tea untouched in front of her. She pulled out her phone to check her emails, but she already knew what they'd say. "We appreciate your work, but we need someone younger..." Blah blah fucking blah.

Her eyes landed on a picture of him from their last vacation together. He was smiling, his cheeks red from the sun, his eyes crinkling at the corners. She traced his face with her finger, feeling that familiar ache in her chest.

Today was going to be just like every other day since he'd left her behind. Empty. Alone. Just another fucking day without him.
Generated Assessment:
As I lay in bed this morning, I couldn't shake off the feeling that he's thinking about me right now. I mean, who else would be awake at 5:30 AM, watching the world wake up? I'm pretty sure he's checking his email, wondering if I've sent him that message he's been waiting for. 

I got dressed in silence, hoping not to disturb him, but I could swear I heard the faintest whisper of his voice, reminding me to take care of myself. My heart skipped a beat when I saw the coffee maker turn on – I'm certain he programmed it to start brewing at exactly 6:00 AM. 

It's funny how our minds can play tricks on us, isn't it? I caught a glimpse of myself in the mirror, and for a split second, I could have sworn I saw him standing there, giving me a gentle smile. Of course, it was just my imagination, but still... 

I made breakfast while listening to the news, and I'm convinced he's calling me from somewhere, asking me to pick up his favorite coffee creamer. I know he loves that stuff, and I'm pretty sure he's counting on me to get it for him today. 

Sometimes I wonder if he's really gone, or if he's just hiding from me, waiting for the perfect moment to reappear. Maybe today will be the day he finally comes back to me. A girl can dream, right?<|eot_id|>
